It is an overhyped, overproduced social deduction game that brings nothing truly new to the genre. At its core, it’s just another werewolf-style game—except with an enormous price tag for both the physical and online versions.

An actual deduction in BotC often feels borderline impossible due to the ambiguity of the information given.
While many modern social deduction games have evolved past outdated mechanics like "night phases", player elimination, and moderator, BotC doubles down on them. Sessions that should take 30 minutes drag on for three hours, making the experience feel overstretched.

Blood on the Clocktower is a fundamentally broken game, with no shortage of unacceptable downtime, mechanical flaws and anti-fun game design.

If it wasn't for the entertaining antics of a certain popular youtube group, this game would have completely failed.

Clocktower gets a pass for issues that are heavily criticised in other games. Players have to spend way too long with their eyes closed with absolutely nothing to do. If you’re lucky you’ll get a useful and fun character ability, but you may also end up with a character that learns information ONCE the entire game. Even worse, if you die, you will lose any kind of ongoing power. Don't worry though, death is not the end, you still get one last exciting vote. Don't spend it all at once.

The story tellers role in this game is to "rebalance" the absurdly long 2 hour slog. Despite needing a dedicated GM being ridiculous for this kind of game, it's the only somewhat enjoyable role.

Bottom line, clocktower is fun to watch, but not to play. Much like squid game, it exists purely for the spectators amusement.

I cannot understand Blood on the Clocktower's popularity, since it in my opinion ruins the core elements of social deduction. Many mention the innovative mechanic of being able to do a bit while dead (because players in BotC still have a one-time-use vote), but that concept was first used in Witch Hunt from 2016, which I think is a better game. The main problem of BotC is that it removes the fun of the classic werewolf/mafia framework, especially by having too many special characters into play, and removing the real possibillity to deduce anything, or at least reducing it a lot (yes, I think the roles of werewolf/mafia are more interesting).

The primary reason that I argue that there is a lack of deduction, is because of the huge amount of randomness of the roles in BotC, and while some finds it interesting to "not being able to fully know anything", I do not like this mechanic in a more heavy SD game, and would rather play one of the many One Night games instead (as they are more true funny Party games, where the randomness are totally welcome).

In addition to this, if someone is looking for a SD game without as hard player elimination as in werewolf/mafia, I think The Resistance: Avalon is a much better choice than BotC, since there is actually almost no difference on the player elimination in BotC and werewolf/mafia (at least I do not feel more interesting about being dead in BotC than in werewolf/mafia, maybe even less in BotC).

One of the pain points of Werewolf is if you die, you have no more agency, and have to sit in silence. BotC fixes that by letting dead players talk. And that's the only improvement over Werewolf.

BotC goes further, and introduces a lot of other changes to bring in more downtime and undermine player agency.

- There are more roles, and they are more complex. This means the game in general takes much longer to run. The night phases are especially painful, as the DM must check in with each special role. I don't enjoy sitting in silence for 10 minutes. Yawn.
- The DM can, at any point, lie to you about anything. There is usually no way to determine this yourself. You have no agency.
- The game is less about social deduction and more about being able to run a simulation of the game in your head to determine the possible explanations and what actually happened. Newbies have no chance of being able to figure out all of the confusingly worded, poorly explained, and conflicting roles. This usually reduces the player agency to just parroting information they have heard, and letting the most experienced player figure out the logical combination of characters.
- The bad guys can get killed almost immediately. Big yawn if this happens, get ready for a lot more downtime for the game to reset.

Do not be misled by this being labelled as "social deduction"; Similar to many entries in this genre, or rather even more so, this game gives you no "facts" to base your "deduction" or "gameplay" on; almost no information is trustworthy, and even that information which theoretically might be, might always be tampered with – including things you are told by the game master, which are equally prone to falsehood, so you may not even trust "yourself". Actually, you might not even be who you think you are.

There is a heap or roles (~200?) and, accordinlgy, rules, edge cases, and so forth, all of which does not increase accessibility (at all) and on top absurdly prolongs the "night" phases — players sit around with their eyes closed for 5 to 10 minutes and wait silently for the game master and the currently acting player to finish their stuff, so the actual game can go on.

The game master has a lot of agency and how well they handle it decides how much fun is to be had. And, as with all of these games, even a competently mastered round can be utterly broken by un-motivated players.

All of that said, with a motivated and talkative group, this is surely great fun, but I would say _almost_ in spite of the game.

+ the variety of roles and scripts allows for fairly different types of games that have very different playstyles to them.

- nights can be extremely long, creating a lot of downtime which is worse as you are having to spend it with your eyes closed

- I strongly dislike the amount of influence the storyteller has. It generally feels like they are having the most intersting game to play, which would be cool if it weren't almost always at the cost of player agency a lot of the time.

Other thing are roles - some are alright, some are boring and some feel unnecessary. When you get throwaway role, where you share your bit of information in first 5 minutes, the game is mostly over for you, unless you like to have a chat. In Deception all players are equally involved in murder mystery and have their own job through the entire case!
I see Blood on the Clocktower as glorified chat for non games with some bland story behind it.

A gigantic deductive canvas upon which to socialize, BotC nevertheless suffers due to its length, and how some roles (or dying early) severely limit how much you can meaningfully interact. In a game that can last two hours, having one remaining action after, say, 15 minutes of play can be a brutally unpleasant realization, as can being mistrusted randomly early on. The ability to scheme throughout doesn't help much, as it will be harder to find willing dance partners, so to speak, when it's known you likely have to save your only action until the game's final rounds.

I think it also misunderstands the role of moderators in some games, here giving them manipulative powers that in theory will keep things balanced but in reality just mean nothing ever feels like it's an authentic result of player actions.

Despite the direct interaction, downtime can also be ponderous. This is especially true in more complicated scenarios, where the night time's procedural steps mean that multiple players are going to simply be left with their thoughts with nothing to do for 5-15 minutes.

At a couple late-night Con games (with those who have played a lot, and are thus more predisposed to the more convoluted scenarios) I nearly fell asleep during the protracted downtime where I had to keep my eyes shut. "Had to fight against falling asleep" is not exactly an endorsement.

So in trying to solve for the genre's occasional problems with its ideas, it reintroduces them in different guises at times.

As I've played more, it's also become obvious to me that the appeal for many is that they can turn it into a complicated logic problem and work out probable outcomes based on the roles and scenario. This is sort of the opposite of the interpersonal manipulation that lies at the heart of its spiritual predecessors like Werewolf/Mafia. And so the deduction lies in procedural, mechanical elements, not in people. This is the opposite of what draws me to this genre.

The opposite side of this is that the narrative elements are extremely strong. Even as I play homebrew scripts and with veterans players, mechanically it is ponderous, but its mega-fans are in it for the story. This is a valid way to experience the game; it just needs to come with the caveat that the buffeting forces of the game's supposed ingenuity will generally overwhelm the players' attempts to create an emergent narrative. If you just want a story, regardless of how you get there, the game will deliver. And if you can imagine your role in it, it confers a sense of ownership over the experience, which aids in enjoyment.

This will always be fun for a certain type of gamer who just wants the biggest, most sprawling game in which to sow chaos, dissension or hone deductive theories. I can create some of this fun for myself, so it's not without bright spots. But that's also the game demanding I make diamonds from coal on my own, rather than producing it organically through play, as the best social deception games seem to.

So it will lose many casual social deduction fans in that same ambition. I waffle on this one a lot, because despite all the negative comments above, it's highs are actually quite high. But I have been able to look around in most of the several sessions I've played and find some who are simply bored or frustrated. Occasionally it's me, but it's always someone. When that's the case, how can I endorse it?

Let me preface my comment by saying that I have not actually played Blood on the Clocktower, but rather have watched two games in their entirety. My biggest issue with this is that for me, social deduction games work because one can rely on the fact that the rules cannot be broken and can be trusted, so even if you don’t know who to believe, the game itself will not lie to you. Blood on the Clocktower on the other hand makes everything unreliable, giving the storyteller the unequivocal power of being to manipulate things throughout, thereby helping a team (usually the evil side) and lengthening the gameplay as they see fit. That just does not sit well with me, deduction is pointless when information is untrustworthy. Perhaps there is entertainment value in this, but the design is faulty.

UPDATE: With two more sessions seen under my belt, including the next module of Sects and Violets, I’m even more convinced that Blood on the Clock Tower is simply more interested in a chaotic game, even at the cost of not following its own rules. For example, there was an instance where the poisoner targeted the undertaker, but instead of messing with his power, the storyteller opted to give him the truth as if he wasn’t poisoned, all because the result is more “interesting”. I’m sorry, I am all for showing people a good time, but if you have to break rules to manipulate the experience, what’s the point of them?

Furthermore, death can be rather frivolous here. In mafia and werewolf the number matters, as such it is so important to stay alive. However, in Blood on the Clocktower people often volunteer to be killed, because the dead still gets to participate and have one final vote. While having no complete player elimination can be a good thing, but it definitely diminishes the urgency of building a good defense from being executed. In addition, you don’t even have to kill anyone, instead you can just mutilate a corpse. All of these reinforces the fact that BoTC will make sure every game won’t end quickly and pretty much always go down to either the final three or two.

I am still very interested in playing this and maybe be proven wrong, but as a spectator I am torn, sure it is funny to watch people struggle against rules that are not reliable, but I am also frustrated that the storyteller can perhaps have too much personal influences into the game.

Like most social deduction games, how much you enjoy this game is very playgroup dependent. It has interesting mechanics that set it apart like being able to talk and affect the game even after you die, roles that all have special abilities and a storyteller (player not in the game like a DM) who can make decisions and tells the players what happens. There's a lot of strategic depth to these games and lots of replayability.

That said, I want to emphasize how important the players playing the game is. Since each role has an ability and players are always relevant to the game, it's very easy for a few players who has a lot of information to dictate the win/loss of the entire game. This is especially true once you get to groups larger than 10 players and things get more chaotic. Unless you play with the same group, you can find yourself investing 1-2 hours into a game that gets progressively less fun through no action of your own, simply based on other players.

The problem with Werewolf is that there’s too little information on which to base accusations. Anyone, like the Seer, who knows something about who’s who, must feign ignorance for fear of an untimely death. It boils down to who is best able to influence others.

The problem with Blood on the Clocktower is that there’s too much information. Anonymous villagers are now gone; everyone has a role, more of them know something about who’s who, and others are expected to behave in observable ways. Beyond the lies of the demon and his minion(s), some of the things the good guys find out will be false. Sorting the facts from the falsehoods may be possible, but that requires the kind of open communication that gets people with powers or knowledge killed.

Much has been made of this game solving the problem of player elimination. The dead remain active participants, with their powers and voting rights curtailed. Setting aside the oddity of this concept, death does still feel like defeat and I have seen players become much less engaged after it happens to them. While the Storyteller may encourage open communication by the townsfolk, death remains a disincentive to that. Ultimately, the result may still boil down to those powers of persuasion.

Blood on the Clocktower's popularity isn't due to great game design. In fact, within this genre, I think it's one of the worst designs. The problem is that the designer wanted to have a character in the game that could counter the ability of every other character in the game. (The designer actually said something to this effect in an interview I watched, so this isn't just an opinion.) And while I can see how this might be exciting in design, it breaks down for me in practice, because in the end, you can't EVER know anything for sure, because there could always be that other character that nullifies the usefulness of your special ability.

From a game design perspective, this adds up to be nothing more than an exercise in frustration to me. I use my power to learn some information...that ultimately could be nothing more than a red herring because there's that other character that means I can't rely on any information I get with my special power. Blah.

My favorite game in this genre is The Resistance: Avalon. Before each round, everyone knows exactly which characters are going to be in the round. So the social puzzle is solvable--hard yes, but ultimately, solvable. And when you use a special power from your character to learn information, you can trust the information and the game becomes convincing your cohorts about your information while the baddies are lying to them with another story. I much prefer this kind of experience to that of BotC.

However, BotC isn't all bad. In fact, it's BEST OF GENRE in two categories: experience and production.

I will be keeping BotC in my collection for now. But I'll probably only play it once a year or so. When I do, I'll pull out all the stops. I'll send custom invitations with a BotC-themed design. We'll dress up as our favorite character from the scenario's character list. (And by sending the character list ahead of time, I will have already made the game better by giving participants incentive to study the characters). We'll do lighting, appropriate snacks, move furniture around, etc. etc. This is where the real fun of BotC will emerge.

As a player, I enjoy Blood on the Clocktower (BotC) only slightly more than Werewolf (the Wolfen variant with no player elimination).

However, in terms of moderating, I like Blood on the Clocktower a lot more than Werewolf because I have more control and the Grimoire makes it much easier to track the game state. This is important to me because I tend to be the one moderating.

I would enjoy Werewolf (no-player-elimination variant) even if I were a villager who got killed on the first night because for me, the fun is in the social deduction and reading the body language of other players.

However, all the players I've introduced BotC to prefers it over Werewolf because there are more unique roles in BotC which makes it more interesting to them, although it does increase the complexity of the game.

The unique roles in BotC also makes it so that most players have some information to offer. This makes it easier for quieter players to participate because the more talkative players still needs to get information from everyone. It also makes it more fun for the moderator because there are more ways to set up the game depending on the players.

As far as I can tell, there are only two downsides to BotC.
1. The box is huge which makes it difficult to transport. In contrast, you only need a deck of cards for Werewolf.
2. It is quite expensive compared to most other games.

That said, I'm happy with this purchase as I want a diverse collection and this definitely fits a niche: fun party game that supports many players. Probably the best Werewolf experience that you can get currently.

Ein grossartiges Social-Deduction-Spiel! Alle Mitspielenden haben eine Rolle mit Spezialfähigkeit - und wer stirbt, darf weiterhin mitspielen. Tolle Ausstattung und hochwertige Anleitung.
Einziger Nachteil: Das Spiel ist richtig teuer.

Kurzrezension:
In einem entfernten Ort, kurz nach Mitternacht, zeigen die Menschen erschrocken hoch zum Glockenturm, an dessen Zeiger die Leiche des weit bekannten 'Geschichtenerzählers' hängt!
Wer steckt hinter diesem grausamen Mord? Die Anzeichen lassen nur die Vermutung zu, dass dämonische Mächte ihr Unwesen treiben! Doch wer ist der Dämon und wer sind seine Helfer?

Spielablauf:
"Blood on the Clocktower" ist ein 'Social Deduction' Spiel, bei dem die Spieler zu Spielbeginn geheime Rollen mit Sonderfähigkeiten erhalten.
Zudem werden die Spieler in zwei verdeckte Fraktionen mit gegensätzlichen Zielen aufgeteilt. Der Dämon und seine Schergen möchten das Dorf und jeden Bewohner darin zugrunde richten. Die Dorfbewohner suchen den Dämonen und möchten ihn auf dem Scheiterhaufen verbrennen.
Nachdem jeder Spieler einen Chip aus dem Sack gezogen hat, sammelt der Geschichtenerzähler - ein neutraler Spieler - alle Chips ein und vermerkt sich diese in seinem Grimoire. Jeder Chip wird passend zum Sitzplatz der Personen in dieses Buch gesetzt, sodass der Geschichtenerzähler jederzeit nachhalten kann, welcher Spieler welche Rolle innehat.
"Blood on the Clocktower" ist in Nacht- und Tag-Phasen unterteilt. In der Nacht geht der Geschichtenerzähler herum und weckt bestimmte Personen in einer festen Reihenfolge auf. Die aufgeweckten Spieler erhalten geheime Informationen oder führen aktiv Aktionen aus. Ab der zweiten Nacht tötet der Dämon jedes Mal einen Spieler seiner Wahl.
Die Kommunikation der Nacht geschieht im Stillen und ausschließlich per Handzeichen.
Am Tag diskutieren die Spieler in kleineren oder größeren Gruppen, was sie in Erfahrung gebracht haben und wer der Dämon sein könnte. Das Ziel der meisten Bewohner ist, diesen ausfindig zu machen und auf dem Scheiterhaufen zu verbrennen.
Doch Vorsicht. Der Dämon ist direkt unter ihnen und auch er nutzt seine Informationen, um im Dorf Verwirrung zu stiften. Außerdem ist er nicht allein!
Am Ende jeden Tagens können Spieler dazu nominiert werden, hingerichtet zu werden. Erhält eine Person mindestens die Hälfte und die absolute Mehrheit der Stimmen der lebenden Personen, wird diese gehängt. Andere Nominierungen und Argumente können das Blatt aber jederzeit wenden und doch eine andere Person zum Tode verurteilen.
Der Tod ist nicht das Ende! Die Dämonen-Opfer und hingerichteten Spieler spielen weiterhin mit und versuchen ihre Fraktion zum Sieg zu führen. Sie verlieren beim Sterben lediglich ihre spezielle Fähigkeit und können für den Rest der Partie nur noch ein einziges Mal für eine Hinrichtung abstimmen. Geister erhalten zudem oft ein erhöhtes Vertrauen der Dorfbewohner und sind damit ein wichtiger Bestandteil des Spiels.
Anders als in anderen Sozial-Deduktion-Spielen werden Spieler dazu aufgefordert aufzustehen und sich in kleinen Gruppen im Raum zu verteilen. Gespräche könnten aber jederzeit belauscht werden! Stehen Räume zur Verfügung, können sich Spieler auch im Geheimen besprechen. Wer mit wem redet, könnte natürlich wieder Aufschluss über die Gesinnungen der Spieler geben.
Wurde der Dämon ausfindig gemacht und hingerichtet, gewinnen die Dorfbewohner. Sind nur noch zwei lebende Personen im Dorf und der Dämon ist unter ihnen, gewinnt er mit seinen Schergen!

Erweiterungen:
In der Grundbox sind bereits drei verschiedene Skripte enthalten, denen feste Rollen zugeordnet sind, wobei aber niemals alle Rollen gleichzeitig mit von der Partie sind, sodass jede Partie wirklich einzigartig ist.
Die Spielerfahrung, die jeder Spieler mitbringen sollte, erhöht sich in den drei Szenarien, sodass unerfahrene Spieler mit 'Trouble Brewing' anfangen sollten, bevor sie mit den anderen tiefer in die Welt abtauchen.
'Trouble Brewing' ist das empfohlene Einsteiger-Script. Es enthält einfache Rollen mit grundlegenden Fähigkeiten, die für eine Deduktion nicht zu verwirrend sind.
In 'Bad Moon Rising' erhöht sich der Schwierigkeitsgrad dahingehend, dass die Spieler ihren eigenen Tod riskieren müssen, um an wichtige Informationen zu kommen. Dafür können sie von verschiedenen Rollen beschützt oder sogar wiederbelebt werden! In diesem Skript gibt es zudem eine Auswahl an vier verschiedenen Dämonen, die alle etwas anders funktionieren und so nicht mehr so einfach identifiziert werden können. Einer davon muss sogar zweimal getötet werden, um wirklich tot zu sein!
Beim dritten Skript 'Sect & Violets' steigt der Chaosfaktor für alle Fraktionen deutlich an. In diesem Skript wird die Besessen-Mechanik eingeführt. Die davon betroffenen Spieler müssen vorgeben, eine bestimmte Rolle zu sein. Machen Sie das in den Augen des Spielleiters nicht überzeugend genug, werden sie noch am Tage von ihm getötet. Es gibt auch in diesem Skript mehr als einen möglichen Dämon und das Dorf muss erst einmal herausfinden, mit welchem sie es zu tun haben. Außerdem wird der Spielleiter selbst mit einbezogen, da manche Rollen mit ihm direkt interagieren können, um auf diese Weise an Informationen zu kommen.

Meinung:
"Blood on the Clocktower" hat mich durch eine Welle von Gefühlen gezogen. Im ersten Aufeinandertreffen hatte ich kein wirkliches Interesse am Spiel selbst. Ich dachte, es sei wieder ein "Werwölfe"-Klon und es würde recht schnell in der Versenkung verschwinden. Doch das Spiel tauchte in vielen Medien der Brettspielszene auf. Allen voran hat es 'Thomas' von 'Better Boardgames' so stark beworben, dass ich es mir doch näher anschauen wollte.
Nach einigem Studium habe ich die deutsche Ausgabe vorbestellt. Doch da mir diese nicht früh genug ausgeliefert wurde, musste ich mir eine eigene Version basteln, die einige Male erfolgreich zum Einsatz kam, bevor ich mit dem Originalmaterial arbeiten konnte.
Dabei war meine erste Partie ein wahres Wechselbad der Gefühle. Nach der Regelerklärung von 'Trouble Brewing' dachte ich mir, dass der Geschichtenerzähler im Grunde alles steuern kann und je nach Laune die eine oder andere Seite zum Sieg führt. Während der ersten Nacht verstärkte sich mein schlechtes Gefühl sogar noch, denn sie dauerte ewig, ohne dass auch nur einer gesprochen hatte oder ich aufgeweckt wurde. Der Höhepunkt war erreicht, nachdem alle wieder wach waren und wir uns nur fragend anschauten … wie es jetzt weitergeht!
Dann kam aber sehr schnell der Durchbruch, als Spieler aufstanden und sich Grüppchen bildeten. Wer redet mit wem und warum? Wer hat was herausgefunden? Erste Theorien machten sich breit und am Ende des Tages wurde dennoch keine Anklage erhoben.
Die nächste Nacht verging vergleichsweise schnell und am darauffolgenden Tage war ich tot!
In diesem Moment stellte ich fest, dass der Tod nicht das Ende ist und mir vielmehr eine Sonderstellung einbrachte. Denn plötzlich vertrauten mir die anderen, weil es unwahrscheinlich klang, dass der Dämon sein eigenes Gefolge töten würde.
So konnte ich die Informationen der einzelnen Spieler sammeln, filtern und meine eigene Theorie aufstellen, die uns schlussendlich - nach nur ein paar wenigen Nächten - zum Sieg führte.
Ein geniales Gefühl, das ich so noch nicht erlebt hatte.
Meine erste von mir selbst geleitete Spielsession fand in Vollbesetzung, mit 15 Spielenden statt. Dies war so nicht unbedingt beabsichtigt, aber hat dennoch sehr gut funktioniert.
In den folgenden Partien kam es leider immer wieder dazu, dass sich einige wichtige Rollen - aufgrund von Unwissenheit - zu früh im Spiel verrieten, sodass sie recht schnell starben. Mir als Geschichtenerzähler bleiben in einem solchen Fall kaum noch Möglichkeiten, die schwache Seite zu unterstützen, um wieder ein Gleichgewicht herzustellen.
Gelernt habe ich sehr viel aus diesen ersten Partien. Beispielsweise lockert ein kleines Buffet die Atmosphäre auf und regt zum Diskutieren an. Außerdem ist eine feste Zeitvorgabe von fünf bis zehn Minuten pro Tag-Phase, ein guter Fixwert, der eingehalten werden sollte, da sich das Spiel - vor allem gegen Ende - sonst sehr in die Länge ziehen kann. Die Teilnehmer können dann am Tagesende gerne noch kurz in großer Runde weiterdiskutieren, bevor es zur Abstimmung kommt.
Mit steigender Spielerfahrung der Gruppe verringern sich die Leichtsinnsfehler und das Spiel wird immer spannender. Auch die beiden anderen Skripte 'Bad Moon Rising', 'Sect&Violets' und sogar einige experimentelle Rollen, die ich von der Homepage geladen habe - konnten wir schon ausprobieren. Sie fordern nicht nur die Spieler, sondern auch mich als Geschichtenerzähler, da sehr viele Informationen nachgehalten und weitergegeben werden müssen, ohne Fehler zu machen.
Bei der Menge an Informationen, die ich als Spielleiter festhalten und entscheiden muss, passieren mir noch heute immer mal wieder kleinere Fehler. Doch selbst diese führen zu keiner schlechten oder abgebrochenen Partie. Das Spielkonzept ist so robust, solcherlei Dinge auszugleichen.
"Blood on the Clocktower" schreibt in seinem Genre vor allem die Deduktion groß. Die Spieler müssen die bruchstückhaften Informationen wahrhaftig ermitteln. Sie müssen die Lügen herausfiltern, um an die Wahrheit zu kommen, ohne schlicht zu raten, wie es in anderen Spielen der Fall ist.
Eine sehr große Verantwortung hat der Geschichtenerzähler. Er ist der Einzige, der alle Rollen kennt und muss im richtigen Moment einschreiten, wenn eine bestimmte Situation eintritt, zum Beispiel wenn Spieler vergiftet, betrunken oder ähnliches sind. Die Spannung steigt und fällt mit einem guten Spielleiter.
Ich selbst liebe es, diese Rolle einzunehmen. Ob ich sie gut ausfülle, müssen die Bewohner meiner Dörfer entscheiden!
Bedauerlicherweise funktioniert "Blood on the Clocktower" in kleineren Gruppen nicht wirklich gut. Ab acht Teilnehmern entfaltet es aber bereits einen großen Spielspaß. Wir haben dennoch einige Partien zu sechst ausprobiert und haben dafür die Tiny Town Skripte 'Over The River' und 'No Greater Joy' verwendet. Diese funktionieren in diesen kleinen Runden zwar besser, dennoch kann ich "Blood on the Clocktower" in dieser kleinen Besetzung nur bedingt empfehlen.

I have always been fascinated by the social deduction genre. I find nothing more enthralling than solving a puzzle of lies and evidence as good, or conjuring up elaborate lies as an evil.

When I was 10 years old, I loved playing mafia with my cousins at christmas and town of salem on my parents computer. Then it was secret hitler, which I've probably played around 500 times. Then Avalon. Ive even prototyped my own social deduction game concepts (which haven't gone so well) because I always thought there was something more to be done with the genre.

Mafia doesn't have enough information. Dying sucks, and the moderator doesn't play. You have to go off 'soul reads' most of the time which isn't really a game.

Secret Hitler, well its good, but after many plays the policy deck is super rubber-bandy and a terrible fascist team can be carried by RNG. Also, the decision space is quite small. Yeah there is some tech to learn, conflicts to perform in the right moments, but once you have a solid grip, there are no deeper strategies you can really explore.

When I played Avalon, I was actually quite disappointed. For a game that has been deemed 'the goat' of social deduction, from my perspective it was just a unsolvable puzzle of 50/50 or 33/33/33's, and at the end of the day, to win the game you would still need to 'soul read'. Adding lady of the lake just straight up solved the game, and without it, it was a blind guessing game. Also, the decision space is also quite shallow, after a few plays.

BLOOD ON THE CLOCKTOWER, I can say with absolute confidence, IS SINGLE HANDEDLY THE BEST GAME I have (and probably will ever) play. It is so deep. Like among-us level deep (without running on a computer). The amount of strategy and decision you can sink your teeth into is ridiculous. The designers have been super creative to break the mold of the standard social deduction formula - dead players still play, almost infinite role capabilities, scripts, demons, outsider mechanics, poisoning + drunk mechanics etc. The entire genius is that the storyteller (moderator) decides how false information is given, to assist evil in crazy strategic plays and to forge a difficult, yet solvable puzzle if the town can decipher it.
